title: How many U.S. states will have a 1.0 or greater effective reproduction number (Rt) for COVID-19 as of 31 December 2020?
preds: Goodness, getting this last distribution like I want it is so hard.  I feel like I'm too low of a number in the 25-30 bucket given that the actual count (32) is closer to that side, but the numbers moved up like crazy in one day, so don't want to neglect the 37-42 bucket completely.  Guess it's time to just let my last forecast fly.

As of today, 32 states are at 1.0 or above. Yesterday it was 23 and had been there for a few days. Likely that reporting backlog from Xmas weekend mostly arrived and Rt will continue to increase for most states. However by tomorrow for this competition, I’m assuming we’ll still see between 31 and 36. Although in another week, I’d bet that we’ll be closer to 43 or more.

The average Rt for the 50 states+DC increased from 0.978 to 1.012 in just one day.  Apparently the folks at Rt.live are seeing the effects of Christmas travel and gatherings.  I was betting it wouldn't show up in the data until 2021.  WRONG AGAIN!  So I'll chase this one back to the middle ranges, but I still won't go all the way to the top bin. Place your final bets and let the dice roll!
This is the "Mr. Toad's Wild Ride" of GJO questions...
Sometimes I forget to follow the rule about not investing in something I don’t understand.

So I'm back where I started. I made the mistake of thinking these updates followed any sort of gradual pattern... that said, who knows where we'll land. @Okanaganopolis & @cdob63 -> https://netflix-is-a-daily-joke.simplecast.com/episodes/fred-amisen-a-joke-about-jazz-and-the-circus-song-v8cyAfEf?t=2m6s @JamesEE NNT is having quite the moment these days...
I think I've been "Fooled by Randomness" a la N.N. Taleb.
the score at refresh TOMORROW (approximately 5:00PM ET on 31 December ) will be the resolution, so I'm back to DEFENSE.  Who knows where the clown car will go next... :-)

What a stupid clown car ride this has become. The lesson is that about a week ago I realized this was going to be a random, unpredictable outcome and I should have played maximum defense and not tried to "eke" out a good score. The question writers should pat themselves on the back for launching such a clown car into the derby. There's a lesson in itself, and one I was blind to.

Big drop in 1.0 or less states in today's (12/30/20) reported data: Down to 19 states in the 'green' vs. 32 'red' by my count. (https://rt.live/) Too much fluctuation:  ..Haven't really been able to 'nail down' the forecast on this one.

Total test numbers have dropped off quite a lot since Christmas.  I bet the folks at Rt.live are pulling their hair out trying to discern what the sparse data means.  The answer to this question will depend on their interpretation of the tea leaves.
Note to self: Avoid forecasting the course of future pandemics.

Currently 23 states are at or above 1.0, with many barely at 1 and plateauing in value. With the reporting delays expected to continue through this week, many Rt values won’t increase until after Dec 31.

The data scientists at Rt.live know with high accuracy the Rt for each state, but only in hindsight.  Sometimes, as has happened recently, the two-week update has a very significant change.  After a month or two the data doesn't usually change very much.  This question asks what will be the first estimate for Rt on 12/31/20.  It's only their best estimate, so yes, we should not expect to be able to nail it down very far in advance. As I understand it the current estimates of Rt take into account multiple variables -- primarily the slope of the average new infections (not sure if they use a 7-day or 14-day rolling average), but adjusted for the number of tests.  If new infections are going down, Rt should be less than one.  But if the number of tests decreases they estimate the number of infections that would have resulted if the testing had remained the same.  I could be in the weeds here, but that's my understanding of the algorithm.  And they may look at other data of which I am not aware.  The key point is that it's an estimate.  The first estimates are therefore highly volatile, pending a review of future data. Maybe it's early for a "post-mortem," but I'll do one anyway.  I give myself a "C" grade.  Fairly early I correctly (so far) underweighted the highest range, but I also underweighted the lowest one.  I concentrated too much on the 3rd and 4th bins, along with many others.  I would have been better off using the more humble approach of putting 20 chips on each of the 5 bins.  I took that approach briefly, but then my mind tricked me into thinking I knew what would happen.  Overconfidence often leads me to over concentrate my bets.  Will I ever learn to go against this tendency?  Probably not.  It's a game with no real money on the line, so I keep trying to win.

The rate of change on this question is infuriating, I strongly dislike this site as a reference. I have accepted that this one is going to be bad since there is no way of knowing where the numbers will be from one minute to to the next, so I guess I will spread it over a few bins.
Seems as though this is creeping up again. It is at 30 again and rising.

Wow, these numbers just keep jumping all over the place.  Of course, the site didn't update for 12/24.  Oklahoma went from 1.11 to 1.00 in one update.....crazy.  I'm beginning to think there is no true way to play this other than spreading your bets across every range over the remaining days and hoping for the best.

Rt numbers were not updated today, and many states did not report their new infections either.  I'm not confident that we'll see reliable numbers until next Monday or Tuesday at the earliest.  The data scientists at Rt.live are dependent on the states' health authorities for the data, limiting the accuracy of their calculations. So I'm basing my estimates (guesses really) on the data reported through 12/24.  My mean estimate is 23 states.  But the range of possibilities is wide, even without a big surprise.

Current status is 28 states at/above 1.0. With the current surge appearing to be regionally focused (west and south) and more Midwest states stabilizing or dropping in cases. Additionally, given holiday reporting constraints, actual cases and other metrics and therefore the inputs to calculate Rt will be likely delayed partially to after Jan 1. Which means the reported value on Dec 31 will be likely underestimating actual values.

I'm now all in on betting it won't drop into last bucket. my squinty eye view of re-playing watching all the bars today vs 2 weeks ago shows many states edging up very slowly and far fewer edging down.  So, to me trend is climbing and I'll invest bottom bucket into the remaining two. @dillyweed how's your read going into the final days?  Merry Christmas BTW!

Current number today is 29 states above 1.0. With one more week of expected surges I think a few more states will go above 1.0 so the highest probability is between 31 and 36. If it holds for another week, then between 25-30, which I think the second most likely range.
We're at 28 states currently, and I confess I have no idea which way it will break over the next 7 days.

Depending on reporting over the next week, I think MA, VA, LA, UT, NC, and MD all have the possibility of dropping below 1.0, and VT and MO are the closest to jumping back above 1.0. Dropping to two bins now, and will monitor for the next couple days.

Another update, I have been swayed by @danbell7819, @Dillyweed, and @Okanaganopolis.  This seems to be shifting in the right direction for the good of the U.S., but it is still all over the place. It is at 26 and seems to be trending down though. I expect it to keep going down while everyone is trying to enjoy the holidays, and likely will come back up following the weekend. I am not sure if it will go up enough for it to get the scales back to looking like it was going to be most of the states, but somewhere in the middle is likely. Shifting to where the numbers are telling me to go for now, but as we get closer it may be easier to dial in on one or two bins.

This seems to be shifting in the right direction for the good of the U.S., but it is still all over the place. It is at 26 and seems to be trending down though. I expect it to keep going down while everyone is trying to enjoy the holidays, and likely will come back up following the weekend. I am not sure if it will go up enough for it to get the scales back to looking like it was going to be most of the states, but somewhere in the middle is likely. Shifting to where the numbers are telling me to go for now, but as we get closer it may be easier to dial in on one or two bins.

The 7-day avg for testing has been decreasing over the past week, and will likely continue to decrease over the next week. Less testing, and less people interested in getting tested, will present lower infection numbers, and signal a decreasing Rt. As of yesterday, 25 states are already below 1.0 for Rt, and the trend is that more will drop below.

This question has honestly become of the bane of my existence.  It seems that they are normalizing the results for test numbers, in effect tracking the positives/test.  I wonder if the spike of testing preceding holiday travel is what is bringing the Rt numbers down so suddenly.  If so, the trend may reverse, but will it do so in time to change the outcome of this forecast?

The average Rt for the 50 states+DC has fallen to 0.988, and there are 26 states with Rt > 0.99.  Kudos to those who predicted a fall in Rt a month or two ago -- @jainsa, @Dillyweed and others.  [Sadly, I was behind the curve.]  We're not quite done yet, but we'll know soon.
The number is ratcheting down.  Starting to look like the holidaymakers' Trumpvirus infections won't hit the books until after 1 January, but there is an excellent chance that I'm wrong about this.

There isn't that much time left -- 10 days worth of data.  Based on current trends I give the following 17 states a 75% chance of being under 1.00: AK, ID, IA, MT, KS, IN, IL, MI, MN, ND, NE, NM, RI, SD, UT, WI, & WY. A further 12 states have maybe a 50% chance of having Rt < 1.00: CO, CT, DE, KY, MD, NJ, NV, OR, PA, VA, VT, & WA.  Other states could make it, but are less than 50/50.  My mean estimate is 31 states with Rt > 0.99. I know these are rough estimates, but I have enough confidence that at least 15 states will be under 1.00 to move more chips away from the "Between 37 and 42" space.  I realize there's a risk that Rt will rise quickly after Christmas, but I'll bet that the time lag between infection, testing, reporting, and recognition of the changes by Rt.live will delay the bounce until 2021.  We shall see.
Maybe its for covid-19 also 'The faster you rise, the harder you fall'
Huge recent widening of the amplitude of the RANGE , (not being a Quant, it confuses me on the implication)  28 at 0 or higher, today 2 weeks ago was 26
Not because I'm convinced of "Between 25 and 30" as the final outcome, but for an intermediate hedge.

Making a further downward adjustment.  "24 or fewer" looked impossible only a short time ago.  We've fallen a long way very quickly.  With 10 days to go this question will come down to the rebound -- yes or no, and if so how much will Rt increase before 2021.

Adjusting forecast again for now. U.S. states currently seem "all over the map" on new cases. E.g.: Some (slightly) improving, some essentially 'flat', some worsening. ( https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/data/new-cases-50-states). 
It's possible that a number of states (especially northern states) may currently be seeing small improvements in spread, after reaching significant 'peaks':  https://www.covidexitstrategy.org/ FWIW: With the holidays almost here, this source currently lists all states except Hawaii as still experiencing "uncontrolled spread":  https://www.covidexitstrategy.org/
Still bouncing all over the place, it was at 32 this morning, now it is at 28.

There has been a correlation in two dozens of states between
low/lower numbers of confirmed new cases and
a decreased level of testing. I assume, test kits (PCR) are still scarce and get re-organized according to acute demand. As new hot spots emerge, e.g. Tennessee, other states with a stabilizing case positivity rate close to or below 10% (which is still too high), will simply receive less test capacity. For the detection of future silent spread, this is bad news.
For the calculation of R(t), this on paper appears to be a success.

We went up by two, from 30 to 32 states with Rt > 0.99.  But the average Rt of the 50 states+DC continued to fall -- it's now 1.017.  It's not inconceivable that the average Rt could fall below 1.00 before 2021.  That appeared to be impossible only a couple of weeks ago. As others have pointed out (@cdob63), with their bets to match, Christmas gatherings could send Rt back up before Jan 1.  "Timing in life is everything." -- John Sculley I'll add a bit more humility to my forecast, spreading out my chips over three bins.  I note that @ForecastingNovice has already taken this approach.
Updated to reflect current trend of States decreasing below Rt of 1.0.  Currently sits at 31

It's coming down a bit now, but it'll go back up when the numbers from the carefree holidaymakers hit the books.  Presumably this will be toward the end of the month or early January.  Unfortunately for us, it matters which.

We're now at 30 states with Rt > 0.99, and the average Rt for the 50 states+DC has fallen to 1.020.  With total new US infections at such a high level this seems counterintuitive.  A few large states, in particular CA, have high and rising infections.  But many states are trending down.  It takes a lot of Wyomings (pop. ~0.6M) or even Wisconsins (~6M)  to match one California (~40M).  So we could see steady or even rising US infections at the same time the average Rt trends down.

35 today... 36 trending up. We were told to expect a Thanksgiving spike around xmas travel... on top of that, we can imagine an overall spike in testing as people are trying to get a hall pass for their risky holiday plans.
Trending fewer states above 1.0 over the last several days, even though reported U.S. new daily cases continue to rise. https://rt.live/, https://covidtracking.com/data/charts/us-daily-positive
Seems that it is going down in a lot of states, with about 4 more near the line.

At 37 as of right now, a few more are right at 1.0. Could move either way though I suspect downward is a bit more likely. I would guess we were at the peak pre-Thanksgiving and Thanksgiving elevated us to a new peak, but we may actually begin declining from this peak nationwide. Some states clearly are which I believe is why their RT numbers are now below 1.
Updated probabilities to reflect number has been trending down.
The site is all over the place, so this one is going to be very difficult to call until the day of.

The 7-day average of new US infections went down slightly today.  Total new US infections seem to be peaking.  Of course it could head up again, which is what happened after Thanksgiving.  The midwest and plains states that had high and rising infections six weeks ago are now declining.  But high-population states, like CA, have been contributing to higher numbers for the US as a whole. Looking at the Covid Exit Strategy website, there are 15 states with decreasing 14-day trends (shown in green), and there are another 6 states with only moderate increases (shown in yellow). https://www.covidexitstrategy.org I may be early, or just plain wrong, but I'm going to put more weight on the lower brackets.

The average Rt for the 50 states+DC has dropped to 1.034, with 36 states now having Rt > 0.99.  This puts us at the top of the middle bucket.  How far and how fast will Rt go down, and how much will it rebound after Christmas?  I don't think we will see "43 or more" any time soon, but we could easily bounce up to "between 37 and 42." There are 10 states between 1.00 and 1.03.  It's not inconceivable that they could drop below 1.00, leaving 26 states meeting the Rt > 0.99 criteria.  So I'll put a few chips on the "Between 25 and 30" space.

RT rates don’t seem to follow an actual forecast path ... even a day or so of downward movement changes them dramatically. It “rewards” improving numbers and penalizes those that are moving in the wrong direction.  Using Missouri as a base (since it is where I have the most Data) the RT rate has gone down, not because it isn’t spreading rapidly, but because it isn’t spreading as rapidly as it did immediately following Thanksgiving.  So suddenly we are below 1.0, even though our testing Positive rate was  17.8% over the last seven days. That is improved from around 20%.  The key issue is whether Holiday Covid numbers will be measured in time for them to impact the RT. Currently, in Missouri (according to doctors and health departments, not state figures) it is taking 3 days for results. It took 5 on my test.  Holidays will slow that down, and tests taken the week after Christmas will not be reflected by December 31.
Flipping my numbers because the states with an RT below 1 keep going up recently.

Current status of is 13 states are below 1.0 and the rest are above. However, most of those 13 are very close to 1.0 (0.93-0.99) and with COVID rates increasing is more parts of the country and additional holiday transmission events to occur, it seems very likely we’ll have 43 or more states at 1.0 or greater.

The average Rt of the 50 states+DC has dropped to 1.048.  With 38 states at Rt > 0.99 we are in the lower part of the "37 to 42" bucket. I believe the downward trend will continue until Christmas.  The big question: what happens after Christmas?  If the Thanksgiving pattern repeats, never a sure thing, the numbers will begin to increase 5 days after the holiday (so around Dec 30), but will not peak for 10 days (about Jan 4).  And further increases might be expected after New Years festivities.  But that's after the close of the question. Moving further away from "43 or more."

Per source: Overall, the number of states (also D.C.) reported at or above 1.0 has generally remained at 39, 40 or 41 over the past month. (https://rt.live/) Effects from Christmas holiday travel/gatherings may not completely show up before the question's time period ends.

43 states above 1.0 Rt currently
42 states above 1.0 Rt 1 months ago
39 states above 1.0 Rt 2 months ago 
37 states above 1.0 Rt 3 months ago
24 states above 1.0 Rt 4 months ago
20 states above 1.0 Rt 5 months ago I would guess the range of possible outcomes is between 35 and 51 States. Current limited data has a slope of 4.89 additional states registering a 1.0 Rt each month. At this rate, 47 or more states by mid January. My prediction for mid November is between 35-47 States (Is 43)
My prediction for mid December is between 35-51 States. (Was 42) The trick is if a number of States will trend down before the end of the year.
Spreading this out a bit in case I am wrong, but I still believe our numbers will continue to get worse and we will be at 43 or more.
Switching 31 and 36 and 43 or more, I think lower is a little more likely than higher.

There is a lot of data dispersion between states.  In ND nearly 11% of the population has received a positive test result, and Rt = 0.92.  Is this the beginning of some kind of partial herd immunity?  How many people have had the virus for every person who tested positive?  Columbia University uses a multiple of 5.5 in their model.  That would imply that over half the population has some immunity.  See Washington Post article: https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/covid-3-milliion-plus-infected/2020/11/18/d9f079a8-2849-11eb-8fa2-06e7cbb145c0_story.html Only 0.81% of VT residents have tested positive, and Rt = 0.99.  Obviously Vermont has done a better job controlling the virus than North Dakota.  Infections are rising rapidly in some states, but the increases seem to be worse in states with high populations and below average cumulative per capita infections (e.g., CA, NY, PA).  This accounts for the rapidly increasing infection numbers for the entire US, while for some states the infections have peaked and are declining (Rt < 1.00). The average Rt for the 50 states+DC dropped from 1.070 to 1.058 today, and there are now 11 states with Rt < 1.00 [40 meeting the criteria for the question].  Many states have increased restrictions.  See article in USA Today:  https://www.usatoday.com/storytelling/coronavirus-reopening-america-map/  I will bet on a continuation of the downward trend for the states that have already experienced extremely high cumulative per capita infections (ND, SD, WI), with the expectation that infections could increase after Christmas in the same way they did after Thanksgiving.  Right now the Thanksgiving increases look like a short-term blip for the states with high cumulative per capita infections, but a longer-term trend for the states that have had lower cumulative infections.

Revising down from the high end. Since RT Live pulls from state data, I expect there to be some inconsistencies as states provide inconsistent reporting during the holiday period. Coupled with likely decreased testing data (either from sites closing for the holidays, labs reducing work load which creates a backlog, or people just not getting tested), I think the data that feeds the algorithm will be skewed towards the lower end.  Of course, the opposite could happen with states providing data dump of testing from the week prior on 28-30DEC, which could cause the algorithm to assess higher Rt values.
Spreading out my chips.  I tend to want to concentrate my bets on the outcome that I think is most likely.  I need to be more humble about my forecasts, and cover a wider range of possibilities.
The average Rt dropped from 1.079 to 1.070 today, and there are now 10 states with Rt < 1.00.  Moving a few chips from "43 or more" to the middle bin.

The average reported Rt dropped from 1.090 to 1.079 today, the first drop this month.  While some states have rapid increases in infections, some states are actually doing better.  There is quite a bit of churn with respect to which states have Rt < 1.00. My guess is that the number of states will now trend down, and possibly go up again right after Christmas.  States like ND, SD, NE and IA that have very high cumulative per capita infections don't seem to have been as badly affected by Thanksgiving gatherings and travel as other states, like CA, NY & PA, that have below average cumulative per capita infections.    For now I will continue to underweight "43 or more," even though we are currently at 44 states.
Adjusting numbers to reflect current trends.
Again no update on Rt.live.  What happens if Rt is not updated on Dec 31?  Use the prior day?  Next day?  Average of prior and following days?
Numbers are going to continue to go up following Thanksgiving gatherings and since all states under 1.0 are 0.05 or less from going over, it is likely all states will be over by then.
We're getting awfully close and as of right now 10 states are below the threshold. Revising accordingly.

I knew that the source *rt.live* is completely non-transparent and unreliable, it obviously  uses freehand-mode to model its curves, and the outcome of their estimate is determined not by the underlying numbers but by political temper or other predetermined targets, otherwise I could not explain why twelve of the states close to 1.0 disappeared from one day to the next, without even a trace. 
They just overthrow their former values, it appears, without any explanation. I shoulda avoided this question, it's of no real use.

New infections spiked upwards today.  Will this be a trend, brought on by Thanksgiving gatherings and travel?  Or is it a blip?  The average Rt for the 50 states+DC jumped from 1.054 to 1.090 over just the past two days.  The Rt.live data scientists apparently believe something is happening.  It could persist, so I'll put some beans on the "43 or more" space, and generally move more chips to the higher bins.  I'm still biased towards more optimistic numbers than the crowd.

Rt.live didn't post an update today.  Based on data from 12/1 there are 22 states with Rt between 0.95 and 1.05.  These could just as easily go up as down, so I'll bump up my bet to 43% on "Between 37 and 42."   That's still below the crowd's 48%, and I'll keep my contrarian bet of zero on the "43 or more" space.  The clock is ticking down on this challenge, ... better keep a close eye on the numbers.
3 month ago, there were 31 states with Rt 1 or above. Expecting the number to be in vicinity of 31 by December end. Will keep observing, probably I will need to go more towards bin 2
Moving a few beans to higher buckets, less optimistic due to Thanksgiving infections.
Thanksgiving travel was a spreader event, and holidays will continue to force people together, currently there are 38 states with Rt of 1.0 or higher, and this will grow.

Distributing around 37 to 42 based on current numbers. Thanksgiving is a big factor that to me makes 43 or more a little more likely than 31 to 36. But on the other hand we seem to finally be at or near a peak in cases which I would think would favor the RT numbers decreasing. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~USA&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=daily&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc

Infections could increase again due to Thanksgiving travel and celebrations, but I'll bet against that until it shows up in the numbers.  While my best guess is that the final answer will be between 24 and 34, I'll keep a pile of chips on "Between 37 and 42" in case there are Thanksgiving super spreader events. @SE_Meyer has gone all in for 31 to 36.  If he's right he'll be the top forecaster for this question.  Being more cautious I'll try to strike a balance between offense and defense.  The good news is that, at least for now, infections seem to be decreasing.

These have been looking better, but will go back up when the holidaymakers start to get sick.  Staying high.   (This is meant to refer to my numbers, not to the fact that we live pretty close to Massachusetts and one of my nieces is a budtender.)
The downward trend has started. Expecting the number of states above Rt of 1 to drop to 23-27 in next 1 month.

The number of new cases has started to flatten in the country as as whole. I am expecting the peak to hold for next 10-14 days and then we should see the downward trend. During the last downward trend, ~25 states were above 1 for Rt. Hopefully this is the last peak.
Small adjustment upwards, in case Thanksgiving causes more than indigestion.

The 7-day average of new infections is decreasing for 8-10 states, and has flattened for another dozen or so.  Is this the peak, or is another wave coming? I think we are near the peak of the third wave of the pandemic.  This has been the worst wave by far, and I believe it will also be the last.  Next year we will have multiple vaccines.  Not everyone will get the shots, so there will be echo waves popping up in many geographies throughout 2021 and probably beyond. With this somewhat rosy outlook I'm completely abandoning the "43 or more" bin.  This is a bet that Thanksgiving will cause limited damage to the outlook.  We'll know in 8-10 days.  Here's wishing a safe and Happy Thanksgiving to all.

The average Rt for the 50 states+DC has fallen from 1.165 to 1.076 since Nov 15.  The number of states with Rt>0.99 fell from 49 to 40 over the past two days.  Rt.live also changed the number for two weeks ago, from 49 to 39.  But the data for one month ago did not change, with 50 states meeting the criterion.  In other words the model is recognizing that the drop in Rt actually began between two and four weeks ago.  Past numbers will continue to be changed to smooth the curve. Although I was expecting the numbers to decrease, I am surprised that it happened this abruptly.  The 7-day average of positive US tests also seems to have reached a peak.  Will this be a local maximum or a global maximum?  Will Thanksgiving bend the curve upwards? I'll stay with my bet that "43 or more" will not happen.  By Pearl Harbor day we should know if Thanksgiving brought super spreader events.
Lower buckets are slowing getting out of reach. But I think we will see the peak within next 3-7 days, thereafter Rt will start coming down in most states.

The current count is 48 states. It was 49 one month ago, 42 two months ago, and 28 three months ago.  New restrictions may drop the rate  in some states. But holiday gatherings coupled with colder temperatures will most likely work to counter the positive effects of the restrictions.  Vaccines will not be widely available (will most likely first be disseminated mostly to the elderly who aren’t really spreading the virus or health care workers) or necessarily have achieved effectiveness in enough of the population to see a significant ant decrease by the end of December either.

If you plot new infections on a log scale the curve is beginning to bend.  Total positive test numbers continue to increase, but the rate of increase is decreasing.  I'll move further down the ladder while I watch the data.  Thanksgiving gatherings could put the kibosh on this forecast.  Here's hoping people will celebrate responsibly.

I think there is a very small chance that new lockdowns (e.g. in WA) push things down in time for the end of the year.... but it’s not going to happen in many states, and I don’t have a great deal of hope it happens at all, especially with holidays approaching.

My thought process on this question has been that reversion to the mean will cause us to end up closer to 50/50 or 40/60.  More specifically, I've been thinking that the wave would peak, especially as Republican governors grew spines after the election and imposed public health measures. By Dec 31 we'd be on the other side of the peak with dropping rt numbers. However, ... certainly my expectations for the speed and magnitude of a reduction in acceleration have been wrong so far. I think the expectation of a vaccine may be taking some of the urgency out of governors to act. Still, I'm betting that we will see some degree of peak and drop between now and Dec 31. The question is (as the crowd has long recognized) that it's between the top 2 buckets.

Skewing right more. Obviously this spike can't climb forever, the question to me is just whether we're on an upward or downward trend at that time. I'm assuming a downward trend could result in RT values below 1 in many states.

Here is a link to an updated scatter plot (pdf format) for Rt vs cumulative per capita infections for each state.  The correlation between Rt and total infections has increased to -0.587.  As states see higher infections the Rt tends to decrease.   https://docs.google.com/document/d/12rXj_R0LAzXy16-NnwwfXFSljdmdzZIwiblJNyC8H98/export?format=pdf So which states will see Rt fall below 1.00 on 12/31/20?  Any number of states could achieve it.  But I'm betting that most of these 9 states with very high total infections (ND, SD, WI, IA, NE, MT, TN, ID & UT) will be among the "winners."  VT, NH, & ME have the lowest total infections, and they are currently experiencing the fastest spread.  Previously the sensible New Englanders demonstrated that they can control the virus.  Here's hoping they will do so again.

As I noted in another question, as the Sun Belt was spiking, RT Live actually had the Rt #s for those states around the 1.0 mark or below. The spike in cases is essentially a 2-4 week lagging indicator of Rt, depending on testing, reporting, etc. Forecasting Rt is trickier than expected.

Still favoring a break in the fever, for some states, within 2-4 of weeks.  New mask mandates and closures of indoor venues (bars, gyms) should also help.  It's amazing to me that although nearly everyone wants schools open, many states cannot bring themselves to close their bars.  I don't get it.

A dark 'picture': Upward trend with Rt over 1.0 in 43 or more states has generally persisted for at least a month. (https://rt.live/). It was 38 states above Rt 1.0 two months ago. U.S. daily coronavirus cases continue to surge "with no end in sight". I've been tracking the correlation between the Rt and the cumulative per capita infection rate for each state.  The negative correlation has been steadily increasing, and is now about -0.42.  I posted a graph (Excel scatter plot) in Google Docs as a pdf for download.  Here is the link if you would like to view the plot. https://docs.google.com/document/d/1O0PGjfqxBDyT6AjRbxbAjQiAXeUFi2gBU8wlGxAbZ6s/export?format=pdf The blue crosshairs mark the average values for Rt and cumulative per capita positive tests.  Each dot represents a state.  Dots in the first and third quadrants contribute to a positive correlation; dots in the second and fourth quadrants contribute to a negative correlation.  As you can see, there are more dots in the second and fourth quadrants.  If you plot a line through the points it has a negative slope, or negative correlation. What does this mean?  Maybe nothing.  But it stands to reason that when a given geographic entity (city, state, or country) has a very high cumulative infection rate, at some point the rate of new infections will go down.  Likewise states that have seen very low infection numbers may be lax with social distancing and mask wearing, making them susceptible to increasing infections and corresponding higher values for Rt. The states with the highest Rt's are ME and VT (quadrant 2), which also have the lowest numbers for cumulative per capita infections.  Mississippi has by far the lowest Rt, and also has experienced above average total infections.  ND and SD are in a class of their own, with total infections over twice the national average.  Rt has recently begun falling for ND and SD.  I expect to see Rt continue to fall for ND, SD, WI, IA, NE, and other states that have high and increasing total infections.  If this happens before December 31, certainly a big IF, then the total number of states with Rt > 0.99 should decrease. Maybe this graph means nothing.  But I was curious about the correlation between Rt and total infections, so I made the plot.  Every day the dots move to the right as cumulative infections increase  Some dots move very slowly (e.g., ME); others move quite rapidly (WI, ND, SD).  Rt is more volatile.  It moves quite a bit on many days, and has generally been trending higher for the 3 weeks that I've been tracking it.  The average Rt is currently 1.161.  Average cumulative infections for the 50 states + DC is about 3.4%. It would be cool to make a "Hans Rosling" type of plot, showing how the dots move over time relative to each other. See https://www.ted.com/talks/hans_rosling_the_best_stats_you_ve_ever_seen?language=en#t-290293 NY, NJ and Ct would be the first out of the starting gate.  Southern states (LA, AZ and others) caught up and moved ahead during the summer.  Now the third wave has seen the upper midwest rapidly move to the right.  Perhaps bubbles could be used to represent to total population of each state.  It would be interesting, but time consuming, to make plots for other geographies.  Just a thought ...
As of 13 Nov 20 the virus infection rate, and R value, is going vertical across the U.S.

@SE_Meyer has taken a bottom up approach, actually predicting which states will achieve Rt < 1.00.  The states he listed with his prediction may very well see Rt < 1.00, but I would add some other possibilities. Rt is a volatile parameter; it's essentially an estimate of the rate of the change of new infections, i.e., the first derivative.  So it can change rapidly.  Several states have very high and rapidly increasing infection rates. My guess, and that's really all it is, includes ID, IA, IL, IN, KS, MI, MN, MO, MT, ND, NE, NM, OK, RI, SD, UT, WI, & WY. Any number of other states could get Rt < 1.00 over the next 49 days, and it's unlikely that all of the states on my list will get there.  But my guess is that the worst states right now (I've listed 18) will be the most likely to achieve Rt < 1.00 on Dec 31. The crowd has moved more towards the highest bin, "43 or more."  I'll go against that trend for now.  If my thesis doesn't work out by early December I'll move closer towards the herd.

The average Rt for the 51 states+DC has peaked, at least temporarily.  It decreased from 1.146 to 1.121 over the past three days.  I'll bet on a continuation of this trend, and move further away from the "43 or more" space.

I believe @Dillyweed is correct in that many forecasters are favoring a continuation of the recent trend, but that a reversion towards the mean is more likely.  I'll go against my natural instinct, which is to concentrate my bets on one or two bins.  While I don't think "43 or more" will be the final answer, I also do not believe we will see Rt down in the lower ranges.

Rt trended down quickly during the first half of summer, possibly due to warmer weather allowing people to spend more time outside.  There are 62 days left in 2020, and it will only get colder from here.  So I'll underweight a rapid decrease in Rt during the timeframe of this challenge.
Cases already increasing in more than 40 states, at greater numbers than increased testing would indicate

Only MS currently has Rt less than 1.00, so the number of states with Rt > 0.99 can't go up much more.  It will go down, the only question is when.  The previous peak of 45 states occurred in mid-June, but it didn't last as long as this wave.  Maybe the reason was that it was more concentrated geographically (mostly in the sun belt). This wave is happening nearly everywhere.  As measured by the number of states with Rt > 0.99 it rose more slowly than the last wave, so I'm guessing it will fall off more slowly as well.  I'm switching from underweight "43 or more" to a slight overweight, and also overweighting "Between 37 and 42."

During the last national downward trend, 14-27 states have Rt above 1.0 Basically this question is will the national trend of new cases be upwards, sideways or downwards as of Dec 31st? I am betting on downwards.

The August motorcycle rally in Sturgis, SD has triggered an experiment that I believe is worth watching.  See https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2020/10/17/sturgis-rally-spread/ The upper midwest, and especially the Dakotas, have quickly moved to the head of the COVID pack.  ND has the highest overall infection rate, 4.2% of the state's population as of Oct 18.  Yet the number of new infections is high, and Rt is currently 1.12.  At the current new infection rate, total confirmed infections will easily exceed 5% of the population of ND by Thanksgiving.  By comparison, nationwide total confirmed infections are just under 2.5% of the US population. Hotspots in other states have ended after 2-3 months.  I believe this one will follow the same pattern as seen for AZ, LA, TX and others.  My guess is that this is not so much due to partial herd immunity, which has been speculated, but rather to social changes.  Having lots of sick and dying may cause people to "get religion" regarding prevention of spread.  "Maybe this isn't a hoax, and masks aren't such a bad idea after all." How does all of this affect the outcome of this challenge?  I'm betting that some of the states with Rt > 0.99 will see reduced infection rates.  Some will go up and others will go down, reducing the odds for an extreme outcome.  Underweighting "43 or more."

I don't suspect we will see fewer than half of the states with an Rt < 1 by the end of the year.  Some of the factors I took into consideration in making my forecasts:
1) Many reopening/phased opening policies use an Rt of 1 as a threshold.
2) Once states dip below the Rt threshold, they start to open businesses again, increasing the opportunity for the virus to spread.
3) Thus far, relatively few states have been able to maintain an Rt < 1 and bounce back up above 1.
4) Cooler weather will bring events inside, and social distancing and other practices are not as effective indoors.  More indoor activities, more opportunity for spread. I'm sure there are factors I missed, I'll keep thinking and looking into this!
Will at least 9 states have Rt < 1.0 on Dec 31?  I'm going to overweight a YES answer, implying underweight of the "43 or more" bucket.

I think the crowd is suffering from a bias to see the current trend continue. I think reversion to the mean (~25) is also a realistic possibility.  Not a particularly precise prediction, but here's my thinking: 
1) all states are trying to get R0 to just below 1.0. They are all titrating the restrictions to get there. On this basis I would expect the long-term average to be around 25 with a wide variance.
2) but ... it could get worse and be out of control in the winter. However in my mind this outcome doesn't change the prediction above because it would start in Oct - Nov (as it apparently has) and states will step in to impose restrictions (after the election)
3) but ... people are getting less worried about the virus, treatments are getting better, vaccines will be tested and talked about. It's likely in my mind that some states will accept higher R0 for longer, pushing the expected number to maybe 30-35 with a wide variance. 
4) also testing is getting better, faster and more accessible, so a larger fraction of cases will be detected (I'm not sure of the net effect of this factor on the prediction because I'm sure the R0 estimation methodology must at least try to correct for this. However, I'm going to modify the raw calculated probabilities from above by de-weighting the lowest bucket which I feel is the least probable. That's my final answer, for now.

Data suggests between 25-36 states, but pending a nationwide lockdown, it could be slightly higher.  Review of the number of cases suggests a relatively high and consistent case rate for the U.S.  Thus, current trends (between 25-36 states with an Rt of 1 or higher should continue.

Hard to tell what their model does exactly, according to the FAQ it accounts for testing and seems to estimate the reproduction numbers that would result in the cases being seen after accounting for lag, so my interpretation is that it updates the numbers from the weeks prior when the spread was happening that resulted in the testing we're seeing now. My guess is at any point in time the last week or two on there are just following the trend that existed a week or two ago. So I think December 31st wouldn't be picking up any effects from holiday gatherings yet. All that may be wrong, but anyway I'm going to guess that we'll regress to the mean a bit and are currently at a pretty high reproduction number. Lots of uncertainty but centering around low 30s thinking things probably won't improve much during the winter and there's always the possibility things get even worse.
As the weather worsens and individuals spend more time indoors I would expect the transmission rate to increase.

(Initial forecast:) The above-1.0 state estimates count (at https://rt.live) for one, two and three months ago total 32 states, 25 and 29, respectively. An average of around 28-29 states (above 1.0) for those months -- but with the recent trend 'worsening' to 38 states at present. Widespread distribution of a safe vaccine is generally not expected until at least early-to-mid 2021: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/17/health/covid-vaccine-when-available.html Improved + quicker testing may help soon, but increased 'relaxing' of societal restrictions plus the possible seasonal nature of COVID may be negatives for the months ahead. (https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/health/2020/10/07/covid-winter-second-wave-may-bad-experts-warn-continued-vigilance/5873746002/) Initial forecast attempts to reflect the current worsening trend in many states, but also the CDC's more or less 'flat' new cases forecast for the next couple of weeks: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/forecasts-cases.html
